channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: AI steps in to detect the world's deadliest infectious disease
item.description: There's a global shortage of radiologists. Now artificial intelligence is helping speed up the diagnosis of tuberculosis in hard-to-reach communities.
item.content:encoded:
There's a global shortage of radiologists. Now artificial intelligence is helping speed up the diagnosis of tuberculosis in hard-to-reach communities.

(Image credit: ARCAD Santé PLUS)
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Emanuel

item.title: Trump urges GOP to end shutdown. And, SCOTUS skeptical of reasoning behind tariffs
item.description: President Trump calls on Senate Republicans to end the government shutdown. And, the Supreme Court hears arguments on whether Trump overstepped his authority by imposing tariffs.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump calls on Senate Republicans to end the government shutdown. And, the Supreme Court hears arguments on whether Trump overstepped his authority by imposing tariffs.

(Image credit: Tom Brenner)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Bird flu surges among poultry amid a scaled back federal response
item.description: Migrating wild birds are spreading the virus to domesticated flocks, increasing the risk of eventually seeing a human outbreak. Scientists are troubled by the muted federal response.
item.content:encoded:
Migrating wild birds are spreading the virus to domesticated flocks, increasing the risk of eventually seeing a human outbreak. Scientists are troubled by the muted federal response.

(Image credit: MATTHEW HATCHER/AFP)
item.dc:creator: Will Stone

item.title: The federal government is still shut down. Here's what that means across the country
item.description: The federal government remains shut down, in what is now the longest shutdown in U.S. history. Reporters from the NPR Network are digging into the ways the government shutdown is playing out in their region.
item.content:encoded:
The federal government remains shut down, in what is now the longest shutdown in U.S. history. Reporters from the NPR Network are digging into the ways the government shutdown is playing out in their region.

(Image credit: Tyrone Turner)
item.dc:creator: The NPR Network

item.title: ICE is sending a chill through the construction industry
item.description: The construction industry, where more than a quarter of workers are foreign-born, has long struggled to find enough workers. Now, industry officials say Trump's immigration crackdown is making it worse.
item.content:encoded:
The construction industry, where more than a quarter of workers are foreign-born, has long struggled to find enough workers. Now, industry officials say Trump's immigration crackdown is making it worse.

(Image credit: Tony Gutierrez)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: The government shutdown is delaying an assistance program families use to heat homes
item.description: The Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program, or LIHEAP, helps about 6 million U.S. households pay energy bills, buy fuel, or fix broken heaters. The shutdown has stalled funds.
item.content:encoded:
The Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program, or LIHEAP, helps about 6 million U.S. households pay energy bills, buy fuel, or fix broken heaters. The shutdown has stalled funds.

(Image credit: Jessica Hill)
item.dc:creator: Sophia Schmidt

item.title: The DOJ has been firing judges with immigrant defense backgrounds
item.description: NPR's data analysis shows that the DOJ has tended to fire judges with immigrant defense backgrounds in its recent rounds of dismissals.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's data analysis shows that the DOJ has tended to fire judges with immigrant defense backgrounds in its recent rounds of dismissals.

(Image credit: Yuki Iwamura)
item.dc:creator: Ximena Bustillo

item.title: Trump plan for smaller SNAP benefits this month may leave millions with none at all
item.description: Under court order to restart SNAP food aid, the Trump administration said it would provide 50% of benefits. But a policy group says the formula for calculating them will leave many with far less.
item.content:encoded:
Under court order to restart SNAP food aid, the Trump administration said it would provide 50% of benefits. But a policy group says the formula for calculating them will leave many with far less.

(Image credit: Bloomberg)
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Ludden

item.title: The shutdown leaves telehealth for Medicare patients in limbo
item.description: Telehealth for Medicare started during the pandemic and became popular quickly. But the shutdown put an abrupt halt to payments for the service.
item.content:encoded:
Telehealth for Medicare started during the pandemic and became popular quickly. But the shutdown put an abrupt halt to payments for the service.

(Image credit: Fotografía de eLuVe)
item.dc:creator: Yuki Noguchi

item.title: Is your electric bill going up? AI is partly to blame
item.description: Across the country, demand for electricity is on the rise — and so is the price of electric power.
item.content:encoded:
Across the country, demand for electricity is on the rise — and so is the price of electric power.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley
